description: From Middle English rousen, from Anglo-Norman reuser, ruser, originally used in English of hawks shaking the feathers of the body, from Latin recusare, by loss of the medial 'c.' Doublet of recuse.
Figurative meaning "to stir up, provoke to activity" is from 1580s; that of "awaken" is first recorded 1590s.

entries.meaning: (military, Britain and Canada) The sounding of a bugle in the morning after reveille, to signal that soldiers are to rise from bed, often the rouse.

verbs.description: rouse (third-person singular simple present rouses, present participle rousing, simple past and past participle roused)

entries.meaning: To wake (someone) or be awoken from sleep, or from apathy.
examples: As for the heat, with which he treated his other adversaries, ’twas sometimes strain’d a little too far, but in the general was extremely well fitted by the Providence of God to rowse up a people, the most phlegmatic of any in Christendome.

entries.meaning: To cause, stir up, excite (a feeling, thought, etc.).
examples: to rouse the faculties, passions, or emotions

entries.meaning: To provoke (someone) to action or anger.
examples: The words they stopped me from uttering may have been very paltry indeed, hardly words to rouse the rabble.

entries.meaning: To cause to start from a covert or lurking place.
examples: to rouse a deer or other animal of the chase

entries.meaning: (nautical) To pull by main strength; to haul.
(slang, when followed by "on") To tell off; to criticise.
examples: He roused on her for being late yet again.

description: First attested in the late 16th Century. From carouse, from rebracketing of the phrase “drink carouse” as “drink a rouse”.

entries.meaning: A carousal; a festival; a drinking frolic.
examples: Fill the cup, and fill the can:
Have a rouse before the morn:

entries.meaning: Wine or other liquor considered an inducement to mirth or drunkenness; a full glass; a bumper.
